intro: Syngonanthus phelpsiae var. cardonae, commonly known as the Cardonae spurge, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing perennial shrub characterized by its succulent, fleshy stems and leaves that are often covered in a waxy cuticle to reduce water loss. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in clusters, which are typically borne on short, hairy pedicels. Its botanical features, including its drought tolerance and specialized adaptations, make it well-suited for harsh, dry environments. Syngonanthus phelpsiae var. cardonae is often found in rocky soils and is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, known for its diverse and ecologically important species.
